meanings.def: two things of the same type, especially when they are used or worn together
examples: a pair of shoes/boots
a pair of gloves/earrings
She pulled on the pair of socks he handed her.
a huge pair of eyes
A pair of hands grasped her shoulders.
a pair of aces/kings (= two playing cards that have the same value)
The winner will receive a pair of tickets to Reykjavik.
The vase is one of a matching pair.
Vermeer painted the two pictures as a pair.
This sculpture was originally one of a pair owned by the King of France.
a clean pair of socks

meanings.def: an object consisting of two parts that are joined together
examples: a pair of trousers/pants/jeans
a pair of glasses/binoculars/scissors
Buy one pair of glasses and get a second pair free.
He was wearing a nice pair of denim jeans.

meanings.def: two people who are doing something together or who have a particular relationship
examples: Get pairs of students to act out the dialogue in front of the class.
Get the students to do the exercise as pair work (= two students work together).
(informal) I've had enough of the pair of you!
They might seem an unlikely pair, but they've been friends for years.
I thought they would make a good pair so I arranged for them to meet.
The pair were matched for age.
They make an odd pair.

meanings.def: two animals or birds of the same type that are producing young together
examples: a breeding pair
a pair of swans
pair bonding (= the process of animals forming a pair for breeding)

meanings.def: two horses working together to pull a carriage
examples: a carriage and pair

meanings.def: in groups of two objects or people
examples: Students worked in pairs on the project.
These candles only come in pairs.

meanings.def: used to say that you are too busy to do anything else
a person who can do, or is doing, a job
examples: We need an extra pair of hands if we're going to finish on time.

meanings.def: a person that you can trust to do a job well
examples: Colleagues regard him as a safe pair of hands.

idioms.def: in groups of two objects or people
examples: Students worked in pairs on the project.
These candles only come in pairs.
He was dressed in a pair of jeans and a white T-shirt.
The teacher decided to pair able students with those who were struggling.
They had to pare the novel down for a two-hour film.
Dessert was a delicious poached pear in red wine.

idioms.idiom: I’ve only got one pair of hands

meanings.def: to put people or things into groups of two
examples: be paired with somebody/something Each blind student was paired with a sighted student.
be paired (together) All the shoes on the floor were neatly paired.
He was dressed in a pair of jeans and a white T-shirt.
The teacher decided to pair able students with those who were struggling.
They had to pare the novel down for a two-hour film.
Dessert was a delicious poached pear in red wine.

meanings.def: to come together in order to produce young
examples: Many of the species pair for life.
